questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of left-sided chest pain. The pain is worse when he takes deep breaths. Over the past 6 weeks, he had been training daily for an upcoming hockey tournament. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol but has used cocaine once. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the left chest. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin is used in the treatment of angina pectoris. Unlike in this patient, anginal chest pain is poorly localized, worsens with exercise, and diminishes with rest. Localized tenderness is not typically seen in this condition. Angina is most commonly seen in individuals with coronary heart disease (CAD). This patient's young age and lack of risk factors for CAD (e.g., smoking, HTN, DM), make angina an unlikely etiology of his pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine that can be used in the management of cocaine-induced chest pain. Although this patient admits to having tried cocaine, cocaine-induced chest pain typically has an acute onset with a duration of < 1 week. It is caused by potentiation of sympathetic response and increased release of catecholamines, resulting in increased myocardial oxygen demand with decreased myocardial perfusion. It typically does not cause localized tenderness with palpation, as seen in this patient. An alternative etiology is the more likely cause of this patient's chest pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent used in the management of highly unstable patients with pulmonary embolism and in those with acute ischemic stroke. This patient's presentation is inconsistent with stroke. Although pulmonary embolism may cause sharp, pleuritic chest pain, this patient's young age, duration of pain, reproducibility on palpation, and lack of risk factors for VTE (e.g., immobilization, malignancy, smoking), make PE an unlikely etiology of his pain. His chest x-ray lacks radiographic signs of PE (e.g., Hampton's hump or Westermark sign). Furthermore, even in the setting of acute PE, this patient would not be a candidate for thrombolytic therapy, given his stable vital signs.

D) INCORRECT:

Heparin is an anticoagulant used in the management of acute myocardial infarction (MI) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Although pulmonary embolism may cause sharp, pleuritic chest pain, this patient's young age, normal vital signs, duration of pain, reproducibility on palpation, and lack of risk factors for VTE (e.g., immobilization, malignancy, smoking), make PE an unlikely etiology of his pain. His chest x-ray also lacks radiographic signs of PE (e.g., Hampton's hump or Westermark sign). The nature and reproducibility of this patient's chest pain, and lack of risk factors for CAD, also make acute MI an unlikely etiology of his symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of costochondritis, a musculoskeletal etiology of chest pain that responds well to NSAIDs. Alternative treatment modalities include hot/cold compresses and limiting painful activities. This condition is a common cause of chest pain in young patients with a history of vigorous physical exercise, as seen in this case.
questions.hint: This young man is presenting with a pleuritic and reproducible chest pain. His pretest probability for acute coronary syndrome is quite low. Given his vigorous physical activity, physical exam findings, and normal chest x-ray, a musculoskeletal cause of chest pain is most likely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of left-sided chest pain that is worse with inspiration. He began a high-intensity interval training program with his friend 3 days ago in an attempt to lose weight after being sedentary and stuck indoors for most of the summer. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke and drinks one to two beers on weekends. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the left lateral sternal border without edema or erythema over the area. There is no tenderness elsewhere or palpable crepitus. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intraarticular injection of lidocaine and triamcinolone

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

For young patients in whom a diagnosis of costochondritis is highly suspected, supportive care (e.g., rest, ice, and analgesia) without further evaluation is appropriate if cardiopulmonary examination findings are normal and there are no identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD). Patients who are older than 35 years of age, have cardiopulmonary signs or symptoms, or have a history of or risk factors for CVD should undergo further evaluation (e.g., ECG, chest x-ray) to exclude cardiovascular causes of chest pain.

Refractory cases of costochondritis can be treated with injected intraarticular lidocaine and/or triamcinolone.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) might be indicated in patients with suspected costochondritis if there are accompanying manifestations that suggest an underlying inflammatory or rheumatologic condition (e.g., morning stiffness, arthralgia, myalgias, chest wall swelling), which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

An electrocardiogram is indicated for patients with suspected costochondritis who are older than 35 years of age, have cardiopulmonary signs or symptoms, or have a history of or risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD). This 28-year-old patient has no abnormal cardiopulmonary findings on examination and has no identified risk factors for CVD.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography of the abdomen might be indicated in patients with pain in the infrascapular region or shoulder, which can suggest a gastrointestinal cause of chest wall pain (e.g., acute cholecystitis). This patient, however, has anterior chest pain with point tenderness to palpation along the costochondral junction, which suggests a musculoskeletal etiology. Therefore, ultrasonography of the abdomen is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Chest x-ray is indicated in patients with acute chest pain and features that suggest a rib fracture (e.g., history of trauma, localized chest wall tenderness), a pulmonary cause of chest pain (e.g., cough, abnormal respiratory findings on auscultation), or heart failure (e.g., crackles on auscultation, peripheral edema, history of heart failure or other cardiac condition). In this young, otherwise healthy patient with suspected costochondritis, chest x-ray is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular injection of lidocaine and/or triamcinolone can be used to treat refractory cases of costochondritis. However, these treatments are not appropriate first-line therapies for this condition.
questions.hint: Acute-onset chest pain that is reproducible with palpation along the costochondral junction in a young patient who recently began a workout program is highly suggestive of costochondritis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-day history of left-sided chest pain that is worse with inspiration. He began a high-intensity interval training program with his friend 3 days ago. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with three days of sharp, constant left-sided chest pain localized to the anterior chest wall. The pain worsens with deep inspiration and twisting movements. She denies fever, cough, or recent illness. Physical examination shows localized tenderness over the left second and third costochondral junctions without radiation. Heart sounds are normal (see report).

Oxygen saturation
98%

ECG: Unremarkable
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Short course of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and chest wall exercises
Urgent CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms are consistent with costochondritis, characterized by localized chest pain exacerbated by movement and palpation over the costochondral junctions. The absence of systemic symptoms, normal oxygen saturation, and an unremarkable ECG suggest a benign musculoskeletal condition. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) reduce inflammation and provide pain relief, while chest wall exercises maintain flexibility and alleviate muscle tension, promoting recovery.

Key learning point: Musculoskeletal chest pain, such as costochondritis, is often sharp, constant, and worsens with movement, and can be effectively managed with NSAIDs like ibuprofen.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan is indicated for life-threatening thoracic conditions, such as pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection. The patient's localized, reproducible chest pain and normal vital signs suggest a musculoskeletal cause, reducing the likelihood of serious intrathoracic pathology. An unremarkable ECG further diminishes the need for urgent imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are used for gastroesophageal reflux disease, characterized by heartburn and regurgitation. The patient's pain is localized and reproducible on palpation, indicating a musculoskeletal cause rather than a gastrointestinal one. The absence of gastrointestinal symptoms and normal ECG findings further support a non-gastroesophageal origin.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous corticosteroids are reserved for severe systemic inflammation or autoimmune conditions. The patient's localized chest pain and normal examination suggest a musculoskeletal issue like costochondritis. Systemic corticosteroids are unnecessary and carry risks, such as immunosuppression, which are not warranted in this self-limiting condition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of left-sided chest pain that worsens with inspiration. He started a high-intensity interval training program with a friend 3 days ago. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 37°C, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. On examination, there is tenderness to palpation of the left lateral sternal border without edema or erythema. There is no tenderness elsewhere and no palpable crepitus. The lungs are clear to auscultation, and cardiac examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intraarticular injection of lidocaine and triamcinolone.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular injection of lidocaine and/or triamcinolone can be used to treat refractory cases of costochondritis. However, these treatments are not appropriate first-line therapies for this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) might be indicated in patients with suspected costochondritis if there are accompanying manifestations that suggest an underlying inflammatory or rheumatologic condition (e.g., morning stiffness, arthralgia, myalgias, chest wall swelling), which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

An electrocardiogram is indicated for patients with suspected costochondritis who are older than 35 years of age, have cardiopulmonary signs or symptoms, or have a history of or risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD). This 28-year-old patient has no abnormal cardiopulmonary findings on examination and has no identified risk factors for CVD.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest x-ray is indicated in patients with acute chest pain and features that suggest a rib fracture (e.g., history of trauma, localized chest wall tenderness), a pulmonary cause of chest pain (e.g., cough, abnormal respiratory findings on auscultation), or heart failure (e.g., crackles on auscultation, peripheral edema, history of heart failure or other cardiac condition). In this young, otherwise healthy patient with suspected costochondritis, chest x-ray is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

For young patients in whom a diagnosis of costochondritis is highly suspected, supportive care (e.g., rest, ice, and analgesia) without further evaluation is appropriate if cardiopulmonary examination findings are normal and there are no identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD). Patients who are older than 35 years of age, have cardiopulmonary signs or symptoms, or have a history of or risk factors for CVD should undergo further evaluation (e.g., ECG, chest x-ray) to exclude cardiovascular causes of chest pain.

Refractory cases of costochondritis can be treated with injected intraarticular lidocaine and/or triamcinolone.

Key learning point: Costochondritis in young, healthy patients without cardiopulmonary risk factors is managed with supportive care such as rest, ice, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
questions.hint: Acute-onset chest pain that is reproducible with palpation along the costochondral junction in a young patient who recently began a workout program is highly suggestive of costochondritis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing and movement. Physical examination shows reproducible tenderness over multiple costochondral joints bilaterally without swelling or erythema. Vital signs are normal, and cardiac and pulmonary examination is unremarkable. The crossed-chest adduction maneuver is positive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Costochondritis can be diagnosed clinically if there are no concerning features in the patient's history and if cardiac and pulmonary examination are normal. Patients should be provided with analgesia and reassured that the condition is benign and self-limited.

B) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiogram is indicated if there is clinical suspicion for pulmonary embolism (e.g., if there are risk factors, dyspnea, or other concerning features). The reproducible chest wall tenderness in this patient makes pulmonary embolism less likely, and another management step is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

The reproducible chest wall tenderness on palpation in this patient strongly suggests a musculoskeletal cause rather than cardiac ischemia, making empirical nitroglycerin inappropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiogram is not indicated as an initial diagnostic test for chest pain evaluation, and this patient's clinical presentation with reproducible chest wall tenderness suggests musculoskeletal pathology rather than structural heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Chest x‑ray is indicated only in the presence of pulmonary symptoms, and ECG should be performed if examination findings or risk factors raise concern for a cardiovascular cause of pain. This patient has neither pulmonary nor cardiac symptoms and no cardiovascular risk factors.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with sharp, localized left-sided chest pain that began 6 hours ago after moving boxes. The pain worsens with deep inspiration and coughing. Physical examination shows tenderness over the 3rd and 4th costochondral joints, and her pain is reproducible on palpation. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with NSAIDs and reassurance

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- An ECG should be obtained to exclude cardiovascular causes of chest pain in patients with cardiac risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Pain on chest wall palpation does not exclude an underlying cardiac cause.

B) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is indicated in patients with chest pain and pulmonary symptoms such as dyspnea or signs of infection like fever, but this patient does not have these symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

While NSAIDs are appropriate treatment for costochondritis, diagnostic studies must be performed first to exclude other causes of chest pain in patients with cardiovascular risk factors.

D) INCORRECT:

The crossed-chest adduction maneuver is a useful provocative test for costochondritis, but cardiovascular causes of chest pain need to be excluded before diagnosing costochondritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Local lidocaine injection may be considered for refractory pain in costochondritis, but it is not appropriate as initial management before excluding other causes of chest pain.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with sharp, well-localized chest pain that has been present for 2 days. The pain is reproducible on palpation of the 4th and 5th costochondral joints and worsens with deep inspiration and upper body movement. Vital signs are normal, cardiac examination is unremarkable, and electrocardiography shows normal sinus rhythm. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy?

choices.text: Topical diclofenac gel and ice packs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naproxen is an NSAID that should be used cautiously in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease due to increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and ulcer recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical diclofenac gel may be considered as an analgesic, but systemic absorption can still occur and may lead to complications in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Local corticosteroid injections are reserved for refractory pain that does not respond to first-line treatments; they are not the most appropriate initial management strategy for costochondritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cough suppressants are only indicated in costochondritis if the patient has a cough that exacerbates the chest pain. This patient does not have a cough.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- In patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease, acetaminophen is the preferred first-line analgesic over NSAIDs to avoid gastrointestinal complications. Heat application is an appropriate supportive measure for costochondritis. This approach provides effective pain management while avoiding potential complications of peptic ulcer disease.
